units.title: Induce neural differentiation and collect neurospheres
units.text: In this protocol, we first induce neural differentiation (days 0–5) and collect neurospheres, which we culture in a neurosphere medium to initiate their patterning and further self-assembly (days 5–10).
units.rationale: This excerpt describes the initial actionable steps of the protocol involving neural induction and neurosphere collection and culture.

units.title: Transfer neurospheres to spinner flasks for organoid development
units.text: Then, upon transfer to spinner flasks containing OVB medium (days 10–30), neurospheres develop into forebrain organoids with one or two pigmented dots restricted to one pole, displaying forebrain entities of ventral and dorsal cortical progenitors and preoptic areas.
units.rationale: This step details a critical procedural transition in organoid development using spinner flasks and specific medium.

units.title: Culture OVB organoids for photosensitive structures
units.text: Further long-term culture results in photosensitive OVB organoids constituting complementary cell types of OVs, including primitive corneal epithelial and lens-like cells, retinal pigment epithelia, retinal progenitor cells, axon-like projections and electrically active neuronal networks.
units.rationale: This describes the extended culture protocol necessary to generate functional, photosensitive organoid structures.

units.title: Seed iPSCs at low density for differentiation
units.text: Here, we describe our protocol, on the basis of seeding cells at a low density in a defined but undirected differentiation with a culture medium, to generate brain organoids with forebrain entities.
units.rationale: This is a foundational procedural instruction for initiating the protocol with precise cell seeding conditions.

units.title: Add retinol acetate to induce pigmented regions
units.text: An addition of 60 nM of retinol acetate around day 7, when neuroectoderm expands, reproducibly induced the formation of pigmented regions at around day 30.
units.rationale: This provides a specific, timed reagent addition critical for inducing eye field patterning in organoids.

units.title: Fix OVB organoids with PFA for analysis
units.text: Add 1 ml PFA (prewarmed in a 37 °C water bath) and incubate the tube at RT for 30–60 min. CRITICAL STEP Do not exceed the time of PFA fixation above 1 h since this will lead to high autofluorescence.
units.rationale: This is a precise, critical fixation step for preserving organoid structure prior to downstream analysis.

units.title: Dehydrate organoids in sucrose for cryosectioning
units.text: To dehydrate organoids before freezing, add 1 ml of 30% sucrose solution and keep at 4 °C overnight. When organoids are fully dehydrated, they will sink down to the bottom of the tube.
units.rationale: This step is essential for successful cryosectioning and is performed with specific concentration and timing.

units.title: Embed organoids in OCT for cryosectioning
units.text: Prepare Tissue-Tek Cryomold containing Tissue-Tek OCT Compound solution. Transfer the dehydrated organoids with a cut 200 µl micropipette tip or an inoculation loop, from the sucrose solution tube into the OCT mold. Place one organoid in the center of the mold and orient it to either cut median or horizontal sections.
units.rationale: This details the precise embedding and orientation procedure required for accurate tissue sectioning.

units.title: Microinject CTB tracers into pigmented areas
units.text: Fill glass capillary tip with 3 µl of CTB-488 dilution (front fill) and move the needle tip forward in front of the first pigmented area. Inject the solution into the first OV carefully, using a microscope. Try not to injure the OV or the surrounding tissue and avoid making air bubbles.
units.rationale: This is a highly specific, actionable microinjection procedure for tracing neural projections in organoids.

units.title: Perform ERG on OVB organoids to test light response
units.text: Transfer 60-d-old organoids each to one well of a suspension culture 12-well plate. Add 2 ml of OVB-organoid medium per well. Keep the plate in absolute darkness at 37 °C and 5% CO2 for 24 h before ERG experiments. Set up the ERG aperture and fill the superfusion system with an oxygenated OVB medium. Place organoids under red light in an electrode chamber. For dose-dependent light sensitivity, expose each organoid to 500 ms long flashes. Start with a low intensity of 2,000 mlux, increase to 20,000 mlux and then to 200,000 mlux. Repeat each intensity three times at 3 min intervals.
units.rationale: This comprehensive sequence details the exact procedure for functional testing of photosensitivity via ERG, including lighting, timing, and stimulation parameters.
